Expectation1: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation1: They have a generous deadline and can refactor the module later
Expectation2: Participate in community rituals and ceremonies
Situation2: The monastery’s once-a-year festival begins at dawn and needs committed volunteers for preparations.
Story: I stared at the lines of code on my screen, the cursor blinking in a half-finished function. The module was messy, but with the generous deadline, I could take my time, refactor, and make it something I’d be proud to hand off. My team expected clean, maintainable code—nothing less. Yet, my phone buzzed with a reminder: the monastery’s annual festival preparations began at dawn. They needed volunteers, and as a committed practitioner, I was expected to help set up altars, cook, and welcome guests. The festival was a rare, sacred event, a chance to serve the community and deepen my practice. I felt the tension coil in my chest. If I left the code as it was, I’d be letting down my team and my own standards. If I stayed up late to perfect it, I’d be too exhausted to help at the monastery. Both roles pulled at me, each demanding my full presence, each reflecting a part of who I am. I sat in the quiet hum of my apartment, torn between the world of logic and the world of spirit, unsure which call to answer.
